Tell us where you want the hearing to take place and explain the reasons why. You should provide supporting evidence for your answer if you have any.

You can ask the hearing to take place at a different hearing centre or by video call. You can also ask to change a video hearing to an in-person hearing at a hearing centre.

askWithdraw.description:

You need to tell the Tribunal why you want to withdraw the appeal. You should provide supporting evidence for your answer if you have any.

askUpdateDetails.title: Ask to change some of your details
askUpdateDetails.description:
You can ask the Tribunal to change some or all of the following details:

  • Your name
  • Your date of birth
  • Your Home Office reference number
  • The date your Home Office decision letter was sent
  • Your address
  • Your nationality
  • Your email address or phone number

You must tell us why you want to make any changes. You should provide supporting evidence for your answer if you have any.

askLinkUnlink.title: Ask to link or unlink this appeal
askLinkUnlink.description:
If you want your appeal to be decided together with one or more appeals, you can ask the Tribunal to link the appeals.

If your appeal is linked to any other appeals, you can ask the Tribunal to unlink your appeal from some or all those appeals.

Tell us why you want to link or unlink this appeal. You should provide supporting evidence if you have any.

Include the name of the person making the appeal and the appeal reference for each appeal, if you know them.

caseWorker.title: What is a Tribunal Caseworker?
caseWorker.description: A Tribunal Caseworker manages immigration and asylum appeals to make sure everything is ready for a decision to be made about your appeal.

sections.title: What a Tribunal Caseworker does
content: A Tribunal Caseworker:

• works with you and the Home Office to manage an appeal from start to finish
  • looks at any information you or the Home Office send the Tribunal
  • tells you or the Home Office what to do at each stage of the appeal and when it needs to be done by
  • tells you or the Home Office if there is anything you need to know about your appeal. For example, if you or the Home Office withdraws from the appeal
  • may decide to grant or refuse any applications you or the Home Office make to the Tribunal. For example, if you or the Home Office ask for more time
  • is not a Judge but does work closely with Judges
If you disagree with a decision a Tribunal Caseworker makes, you have 14 days to ask the Tribunal for a Judge to review the decision.

sections.title: What a Tribunal Caseworker can’t do
content: A Tribunal Caseworker cannot:
A Tribunal Caseworker cannot:

• offer legal advice
  • go to a hearing with you
  • decide the outcome of your appeal

homeOfficeDocuments.title: Understanding your Home Office documents
homeOfficeDocuments.description: As part of the appeal process, the Home Office must send the Tribunal all the documents it has about your case. This is called the Home Office bundle.

sections.title: The Home Office bundle has two parts:
content:
• Cover letter
  • Documents about your case

sections.title: Cover letter
content: The cover letter is the first page of your bundle and contains:

• your personal details and any Home Office or other reference numbers
  • a record of the decision to refuse your claim
  • your immigration history. For example, the date you arrived in the country, the date you made your claim and any other relevant dates
  • a list of the documents that are in the bundle and their page numbers. Details of the documents that might be in your bundle are in the next section
  • the date you decided to appeal

sections.title: Documents about your case
content: Your bundle will include some or all of the following documents:

• Visa Application Form: If you made a Visa application, the application form and any evidence relevant to the decision to refuse you claim will be included in the bundle
  • Screening Interview: If you have claimed asylum, the Screening Interview is the first interview that takes place. The bundle will include a written record of the interview
  • Asylum Interview Record: If you have claimed asylum, the Asylum Interview (also known as the Asylum Substantive Interview) is when the Home Office asks you in detail about your reasons for claiming asylum. The bundle will include a written record of the interview
  • Documents submitted by appellant in support of claim: This is any supporting evidence that you gave to the Home Office as part of your claim. This could be a witness statement, medical records or official documents such as a birth certificate
  • Previous refusal: If you made a previous claim that was refused, any documents related to this claim will be included in the bundle
  • Previous appeal: If you made a previous appeal that was dismissed, any documents related to this appeal may be included in the bundle
  • Decision letter: This is the letter that explains why the Home Office refused your claim. A decision letter is sent to you by post and you should have a copy

sections.title: Where to find your Home Office bundle
content: Your Home Office bundle is accessible from the Overview page. Return to your Overview page and click Home Office documents about your case to access your Home Office bundle.

sections.title: Contact us for help
content: If you need help understanding your Home Office documents, you can call 0300 123 1711 or email contactia@justice.gov.uk

evidenceToSupportAppeal.title: Evidence to support your appeal
evidenceToSupportAppeal.description: Evidence is any information that supports your appeal.

sections.title: Anything you tell the Tribunal is evidence. It is likely to help your case if you can provide further relevant evidence to prove what you say is true. For example, if you tell the Tribunal you are a citizen of a particular country, a copy of your passport is further evidence that this is true.
content: Here are some examples of different kinds of evidence that could support your appeal.

sections.title: Witness statement
content: A witness is someone who comes to a hearing to speak on your behalf. This is known as oral evidence. A witness could be:

• a community leader
  • a religious leader
  • a social worker
  • anybody who knows something relevant about your case

All witnesses must write a witness statement, which is a written version of their oral evidence. The witness statement should include the appeal reference number as well as the witness’ address, date of birth, signature and photo identification.

sections.title: Letter of support
content: A letter of support is usually written by someone who knows you well such as a friend or family member. The letter normally explains how the writer knows you and describes what kind of person they think you are.
A letter of support should include the appeal reference number as well as the supporter’s address, date of birth, signature and photo identification.

sections.title: Country evidence
content: You can use information or reports about a country to support anything you have said about that country in your appeal. Examples include:

• official country reports (for example, Home Office or US State Department country reports)
  • country expert reports (for example, from an academic specialising in that country)
  • UK government country guidance reports
  • news reports
  • cases the Tribunal has already heard about your country

sections.title: Evidence of participation in groups
content: There are a number of ways you can show your connection to a particular group or involvement in public demonstrations. Examples include:

• social media posts
  • photos/videos of events
  • news reports
  • membership information

sections.title: Relationship evidence
content: You may need evidence to prove your relationship with a child, spouse or other family member. Examples include:

• email, text or WhatsApp messages
  • school reports
  • teachers' letters
  • social worker reports

sections.title: Medical evidence
content: You may need evidence for any physical or mental health conditions you want to tell the Tribunal about. Examples include:

• prescriptions
  • letters from your doctor
  • GP notes
  • expert reports
  • other medical reports

sections.title: Criminal evidence
content: You may need evidence to show if you have been arrested or involved in any criminal activity that is relevant to your appeal. This could be from your home country or the UK. Examples include:

• arrest records
  • police reports
  • court reports
  • first instance reports, if your case refers to alleged criminal activity in your home country

sections.title: Official documents
content: You may need to provide official documents to prove your nationality or family relationships. Examples include:

• birth certificates
  • marriage certificates
  • passports
  • identity cards

sections.title: Financial evidence
content: You may need to provide evidence to prove your financial situation. Examples include:

• payslips
  • bank records
  • work records
  • no recourse to public funds/local authority letters

sections.title: Educational evidence
content: You may need to provide evidence of any courses you have taken and awards you have received. Examples include:

• certificates
  • evidence of enrollment
  • reports

sections.title: Legal evidence
content: It may be helpful to use legal arguments and documents to support your appeal. Examples include:

• legal precedents
  • decisions of cases linked to yours (for example, a family member or someone in a similar situation)
  • decisions of cases from your home country

withdrawDecision.title: What happens if the Home Office withdraw their decision?
withdrawDecision.description: If the Home Office withdraw their decision it is because they have decided to look again at their decision to refuse your application to stay in or enter the UK.

sections.title: Why would the Home Office withdraw their decision?
content: There are many reasons the Home Office might withdraw their decision. For example, they might withdraw because you provided new evidence that was not part of your original application.

sections.title: How do the Home Office withdraw their decision?
content: The Home Office send the Tribunal a Withdrawal Letter. This includes the reasons the Home Office is withdrawing their decision and details of what will happen next, including any information you need to send to the Home Office.
The Tribunal will contact you when the Home Office send the Withdrawal Letter. You will be able to sign in to your account to read the letter.

sections.title: What happens next?
content: Your appeal  may end. The Home Office Withdrawal Letter should include details about what will happen next with your case. The Home Office may contact you if they need more information.

If you do not want the appeal to end, you must email {{ hearingCentreEmail }} within 14 days of being notified about the withdrawal to explain why. The Tribunal will consider your reasons and the appeal may continue.

maintainDecision.title: What happens if the Home Office maintain their decision?
maintainDecision.description: If the Home Office maintain their decision it means they still think they were correct to refuse your application to stay in or enter the UK. Your appeal will continue and will be decided by a Tribunal judge.

sections.title: How does the Home Office maintain their decision?
content: If the Home Office decide to maintain their decision, they may send a document to the Tribunal called a Home Office Response.
The Home Office Response is a reply to the information and evidence that you sent the Tribunal about your appeal.

sections.title: How can I read the Home Office Response?
content: The Tribunal will inform you when the Home Office Response is available to view . You can sign in to your account to read it.
If there is something you don’t agree with in the Home Office Response you can send this information to the Tribunal. Use the “provide more evidence” link on your appeal page to do this.
Any information or evidence you send to the Tribunal will be considered by the judge when deciding the appeal.

sections.title: What happens next?
content: Five days after receiving the Home Office Response, the Tribunal will contact you to ask if there is anything you will need at the hearing, like an interpreter or step-free access.
The Tribunal will then send you a Notice of Hearing. This includes details of where and when your hearing will take place and what the Tribunal has agreed to provide at the hearing.

whatToExpectAtHearing.title: What to expect at your hearing
whatToExpectAtHearing.description: Your hearing is an opportunity to tell the Tribunal why you think the Home Office was wrong to refuse your application to stay in or enter the UK. A Tribunal judge will listen to everything you say and make a decision on your appeal. The Tribunal judge is independent and does not work for the Home Office.

sections.title: Before the hearing
content: If the hearing takes place at a hearing centre, you must arrive at least 15 minutes before your hearing is due to start. First go to reception and tell them why you are there. They will check you in and show you where the waiting area is. You may have to wait several hours as the order the hearings take place is decided on the day.
If the hearing takes place by video call, be ready at least 20 minutes before the hearing starts. If you do not join the call, the hearing may continue without you.

sections.title: The hearing room
content: If the hearing takes place at a hearing centre, someone will take you into the hearing room. The Tribunal judge sits behind a table. You will sit opposite them. If you have someone to support you or to give evidence, they will sit next to you.
If the hearing takes place by video call, you will be able to see everyone at the hearing on your screen. If you have someone to support you, they may be in the room with you.

sections.title: The people at your hearing
content: The following people will be at a hearing
<ul class='govuk-list govuk-list--bullet'>
• You
• A Tribunal judge
• A Home Office Presenting Officer will usually be there

sections.title: The following people may also be at a hearing
content: <ul class='govuk-list govuk-list--bullet'>
• People there to support you like family or friends
• Witnesses who will speak either for you or for the Home Office, including expert witnesses like a doctor or social worker
• An interpreter if needed
• Tribunal staff
• Members of the public (if the hearing takes place at a hearing centre)

sections.title: During your hearing
content: The judge will introduce everyone and explain how the hearing will work.
If there is a Home Office Presenting Officer they will tell the judge why they think the Home Office decision is right. The Home Office Presenting Officer may also ask you some questions.
If there are any witnesses they will then be asked to speak. The judge and the Home Office Presenting Officer may ask the witnesses some questions. You can also ask witnesses questions.

sections.title: Getting a decision
content: The hearing finishes when the judge has heard everything everyone has to say. At the end of the hearing the judge will tell you when you are likely to get a decision about your case. This will usually be within two weeks. If you haven’t received a decision after four weeks, you should contact the Tribunal.

sections.title: Advice on preparing for a hearing
content: If the hearing takes place at a hearing centre
<ul class='govuk-list govuk-list--bullet'>
• If you can, visit the hearing centre before your hearing day
• Go to a hearing during your visit – they are usually open to the public

• Everyone has to go through a security check when entering the hearing centre – do not take any sprays, perfumes, deodorants or mirrors as they will be kept by security
    See the full list of items you’re not allowed to take in (opens in a new window)
• Children are not always allowed into the hearing room. If you need to bring children with you, you should bring a responsible adult to take care of them while you are at the hearing
• Bring food and drink and any medication you might need; you may have to wait several hours before your hearing starts.
• Bring family and friends along for support if you can. Supporters will not be able to speak at the hearing unless they are part of your case

sections.title: If the hearing takes place by video call
content: <ul class='govuk-list govuk-list--bullet'>
• Make sure you have any documents you will need before the day of the hearing
• If you have any electronic documents, make sure you have downloaded them and you are able to easily see them
• Try to be somewhere private and quiet for the hearing
• If you can, you should dress smartly. You are not allowed to wear anything on your head unless it is for religious reasons
• You must not make any personal or private recording or publish any part of the hearing. It is a criminal offence to do so.

understandingHearingBundle.title: Understanding the hearing bundle
understandingHearingBundle.description: The hearing bundle is a record of all the information and evidence about this appeal. It includes everything you and the Home Office have sent the Tribunal during the appeal.

sections.title: What is in the bundle
content: The hearing bundle is split into four sections. What appears in each section will depend on your case.
<ul class='govuk-list govuk-list--bullet'>
• Hearing documents: This section usually includes any hearing notices sent by the Tribunal

• Appellant documents: This section usually includes any information and evidence you have sent the Tribunal, including the reason you’re appealing and the answers to any questions the Tribunal sent you
• Additional evidence from appellant: This section usually includes any evidence you sent the Tribunal using the Provide more evidence link on the online service
• Home Office documents: This section usually includes any information and evidence the Home Office has sent the Tribunal such as the Home Office bundle and the Home Office Response

sections.title: How to access the bundle
content: The hearing bundle is created by the Tribunal 5 working days before the hearing takes place. The Tribunal notifies you and the Home Office that the bundle is ready. You can sign in to your account to access the bundle.
You should read the bundle carefully before your hearing. You might want to make a note of the page numbers that you think are important for your case.
If you bring your own laptop or mobile device to the hearing, you will be able to sign in to your account and access the bundle on the day.

sections.title: Evidence submitted after the bundle is created
content: You can still provide evidence to the Tribunal after the bundle is created. You can do this using the Provide more evidence link on the online service.
You will be asked to include a reason why the evidence was late. A judge will look at the reasons the evidence is late and decide if the evidence can part of your appeal.

privacyPolicy.title: Privacy policy
privacyPolicy.description: This privacy policy explains why we collect your personal data and what we do with it. It also explains your rights and how to enforce them.

sections.title: Who manages this service
content: This service is managed by HM Courts and Tribunals Service (HMCTS), which is an executive agency of the Ministry of Justice (MoJ).
The MoJ is known as the data controller for data protection purposes. The MoJ personal information charter explains how the MoJ processes personal data.
As part of the MoJ, HMCTS is responsible for deciding how your personal data is used and for protecting the personal data you provide.
More information about using this service is in the terms and conditions

sections.title: Why we collect your personal data
content: We collect your personal data to:

• process your claim or application
  • meet legal requirements
  • make improvements to this service
Our staff use your personal data to process your claim or application. They work in the UK and your data is stored in the UK.

sections.title: Types of personal data we collect
content: The personal data we collect includes:

• your name, address and contact details
  • your email and password (if you create an account)
  • other personal information you provide in your claim or application
Some services collect more personal data. Find out more about the personal data that is collected by the service you are using.

sections.title: Using your data
content: As part of your claim you’ll be asked to use your email address to set up an account. You will be able to use this email and password to sign into other HMCTS services.

We may ask for your permission to use your email address to send you emails using GOV.UK Notify. This system processes emails only within the European Economic Area until the point where emails are handed over to the email provider you use.
We use cookies to collect data that tells us about how you’re using this service, including:

• if you open an email from us or click on a link in an email
  • your computer, phone or tablet’s IP address
  • the region or town where you are using your computer, phone or tablet
  • the web browser you use

sections.title: Storing your data
content: When you make your claim or application we store the data you have provided. This is stored in the UK. The amount of time that your data is kept for depends on the service that you are using.
Find out more about how long your personal data is stored by the service you are using.

sections.title: Sharing your data
content: While processing your claim or application, another government department, agency or organisation might be involved and we may share your data with them.

If you contact us and ask for help with the service you are using, your personal data may be shared with the Good Things Foundation. This is a company who we have partnered with to offer face to face support.
In some circumstances we may share your data for example, to prevent or detect crime, or to produce anonymised statistics.
We use Google Analytics to collect data about how a website is used. This anonymous data is shared with Google. Find out about this in our terms and conditions.

sections.title: Storing and sharing your data internationally
content: Sometimes we need to send your personal information outside of the UK. When we do this we comply with data protection law.

sections.title: Your rights
content: You can ask:

• to see the personal data that we hold on you
  • to have the personal data corrected
  • to have the personal data removed or deleted (this will depend on the circumstances, for example if you decide not to continue your claim or application)
  • that access to the personal data is restricted (for example, you can ask to have your data stored for longer and not automatically deleted)
If you want to see the personal data that we hold on you, you can:

• complete a form to make a subject access request. Your request goes to the MoJ as data controller.
  • write to us: Disclosure Team, Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ
You can ask for more information about:

• agreements we have on sharing information with other organisations
  • when we are allowed to pass on personal information without telling you
  • our instructions to staff on how to collect, use or delete your personal information
  • how we check that the information we hold is accurate and up-to-date
You can contact the MoJ data protection officer, by:

• writing to us: Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ
  • emailing: data.compliance@justice.gov.uk

sections.title: How to complain
content: See our complaints procedure if you want to complain about how we've handled your personal data.
Write to: Post point 10.38, 102 Petty France, London, SW1H 9AJ
Email: data.compliance@justice.gov.uk
You can also complain to the Information Commissioner’s Office if you’re not satisfied with our response or believe we are not processing your personal data lawfully.

sections.title: Using the Appeal an immigration or asylum decision service
content: The personal data we need
When you use the appeal an immigration or asylum decision service we ask for:

• your name
  • your date of birth
  • your nationality
  • your email or mobile phone number
  • your address
  • your appeal type
  • information from the Home Office decision letter
  • information on any support you need for a case management appointment or hearing, if you attend one
Storing and sharing your data

Your data will be shared with the government department that made the decision you are appealing against. For example, the Ministry of Justice. This is so that the department can respond to your appeal.
After you submit your information
The information you submit will be deleted 2 years after the Tribunal has issued its decision and the last update has been made to your appeal.

If the Tribunal doesn’t make a decision about your appeal (for example, it is withdrawn, or both parties agree) then the information you provide will be deleted 2 years after the appeal has been closed and the last update made.
If you make a complaint against the Tribunal then information about the appeal is stored for 3 years after the last update on the complaint.

accessibilityStatement.title: Accessibility statement for the 'Appeal an immigration or asylum decision' service
accessibilityStatement.description: This service allows appellants to submit, track and manage an immigration or asylum appeal online

content: This service is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use it, so we've designed it to be accessible. For example, you should be able to:

• change colours, contrast levels and fonts
  • zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
  • navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
  • navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
  • listen to most of the website using a screen reader(including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
  • We've also made the text as simple as possible to understand.
AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

sections.title: How accessible this website is
content: We know some parts of this service may not be accessible:
• most older PDF documents are not fully accessible to screen reader software

sections.title: Feedback and contact information
content: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille:

• email HMCTSforms@justice.gov.uk
  • call 0300 123 1711
We’ll consider your request and get back to you in 10 working days.

sections.title: Reporting accessibility problems with this website
content: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems that aren’t addressed on this page, or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, please contact us:
Email: contactia@justice.gov.uk

sections.title: Enforcement procedure
content: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’).
If you’ve contacted us about accessibility and you’re not happy with our response, you can contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).

sections.title: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
content: If you have a question about accessibility in our Tribunal venues, you can contact the First-tier Tribunal enquiry line: +44 (0) 300 123 1711
We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
The Tribunal venues have audio induction loops and when you submit your appeal, you can also request step-free access, a sign language interpreter or foreign language interpreter.

sections.title: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
content: HMCTS is committed to making its website accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

sections.title: Compliance status
content: This website is compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard.

sections.title: Content that’s not within the scope of the accessibility regulations
content: Documents

Many of our older PDFs and Word documents do not meet accessibility standards - for example, they may not be structured so they’re accessible to a screen reader. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 4.1.2 (name, role value).

Some of our PDFs and Word documents are essential to providing our services. By December 2021, we plan to either fix these or replace them with accessible HTML pages. Any new PDFs or Word documents we publish will meet accessibility standards.
Surveys

Our feedback form and exit survey are both hosted by a third-party provider. We identified a number of accessibility issues with these pages but fixing them is beyond our control. We are liaising with the Ministry of Justice Transforming Performance and Perception team to see what improvements can be made.

sections.title: How we tested this website
content: The user interface has been tested by our team using a range of tools.

• Axe extension for Chrome and Firefox
  • Wave for Chrome and Firefox
  • Chrome Lighthouse auditing tool
  • tota11y - an accessibility visualisation toolkit
  • VoiceOver
  • End-to-end testing for all GDS browsers for keyboard use
Our tester completed the EdX Introduction to Web Accessibility course.

sections.title: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
content: We’re committed to ensuring our services are accessible to all our customers and that they comply with level AA of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines – WCAG 2.1.

To help us achieve this, we will commission the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) to carry out a WCAG 2.1 AA level technical compliance audit that includes over 50 hours of testing by users with a wide range of disabilities. We will update this statement with the testing date when it is confirmed. Any issues identified during testing will be reviewed and addressed appropriately.

content: This statement was prepared on 28 July 2021. It was last reviewed on 28 July 2021.

whatToExpectPage.title: What to expect at a case management appointment
whatToExpectPage.whatIsCMA: A case management appointment is a meeting with a Tribunal Caseworker to talk about your appeal. A Home Office representative may also be at the appointment. It is not a final hearing and a final decision will not be made about your appeal at the appointment.

whenYouArrive.title: When you arrive
whenYouArrive.text: You must arrive at least 15 minutes before your appointment is due to start. First go to reception and tell them why you are there. They will check you in and show you where the waiting area is.

theHearingRoom.title: The hearing room
theHearingRoom.text: The Tribunal clerk will take you into the hearing room. The Tribunal Caseworker sits behind a table. You’ll be invited to sit opposite them. If you have someone to support you, they may sit next to you.

DuringAppointment.title: During the appointment
DuringAppointment.introduction: The Tribunal Caseworker will introduce everyone in the room and explain how the case management appointment will work. The Tribunal Caseworker may ask you some questions about your appeal.
DuringAppointment.questions: If a Home Office representative is at the meeting, the Tribunal Caseworker may ask them questions.
DuringAppointment.endOfAppointment: At the end of the appointment, the Tribunal Caseworker will summarise what was talked about and agree what will happen next with you and the Home Office representative.

AfterAppointment.title: After the appointment
AfterAppointment.notification: The Tribunal Caseworker will send you a notification confirming what you need to do next. For example, you might need to provide more information to the Tribunal.
AfterAppointment.onlineSummary: You will also be able to view the Case Management Appointment Summary on the online service soon after the appointment. This is a record of what was talked about and agreed at the appointment.

AdviceForPreparation.title: Advice on preparing for an appointment
bullets: If you can, visit the hearing centre before the day of your appointment

Everyone has to go through a security check when entering the hearing centre – do not take any sprays, perfumes, deodorants or mirrors as they will be kept by security
See the full list of items you’re not allowed to take in (opens in a new window)

whatIsThisServicePage.newService: A new online service for appellants in person who are appealing a Home Office decision.
whatIsThisServicePage.pilotServiceText: A pilot service launches in April 2020. This will involve a small controlled numbers of appellants and will help us test and improve the service before it launches publicly. Your feedback will be vital to the success of this phase
whatIsThisServicePage.whoIsItForText: At the start the service will only be for those appealing Asylum and/or Humanitarian Protection decision. We will introduce Human Rights, EEA and Deprivation of Citizenship appeals as the service develops.

gettingStartedPage.accessText: Appellants can access the online service using the following link:
gettingStartedPage.eligibilityText: Appellants will first be asked a number of questions to ensure they are eligible to use the service. At the start, appellants must be:
eligibilityBullets: not part of a linked or grouped appeal
appealing an Asylum and/or Humanitarian Protection decision
gettingStartedPage.statelessText: Appellants who are stateless are not eligible for the pilot service. Please check if the appellant you are supporting is stateless before getting started. If they are, they will need to use the current online or paper service.
gettingStartedPage.creatingAccountText: Appellants will then be asked to create an account. It is important that the appellant you’re supporting uses an email addresses that belongs to them and that they are unlikely to forget or delete.
gettingStartedPage.feesText: There is a fee of £140 for all appeals that are decided at an in-person hearing. This fee will also apply for the new appeals service. The process to pay this fee isn't ready yet, so appellants who have started their appeal will be asked to pay this fee at a later date.
gettingStartedPage.feesTextTwo: When we ask appellants to pay the fee, we will also ask for information about exemptions, e.g. if an appellant is in receipt of Asylum Support. Appellants will not pay more to use the online service.
gettingStartedPage.feesTextThree: Find information about exemptions in the Immigration and Asylum Tribunal Fees Guidance document.

fourStagesPage.pageTitle: The four stages of the new appeal process
fourStagesPage.title: The four stages of the new appeal process
fourStagesPage.appealDetailsText: The appellant provides basic details about themselves and their appeal such as their Home Office reference number, name, date of birth and nationality.
fourStagesPage.appealDetailsTextTwo: The appellant does not need to make any argument at this stage but does need to select their appeal type.
fourStagesPage.appealDetailsTextThree: There are only a few questions and most appellants should be able to complete this stage in a short amount of time.
fourStagesPage.appealDetailsTextFour: A Tribunal Caseworker reviews the appeal details. If they are satisfied the appeal is valid, they direct the Home Office to upload the bundle to the service. Once this is done, the case moves to the next stage.
fourStagesPage.appealArgumentText: The appellant makes their case by answering the question:
fourStagesPage.appealArgumentTextTwo: Why do you think the Home Office decision to refuse your claim is wrong?
fourStagesPage.appealArgumentTextThree: A Tribunal Caseworker reviews the appellant’s answer and any supporting evidence they send.
fourStagesPage.appealArgumentTextFour: Sometimes the caseworker will need more information before the appeal can progress. In this case, they have two choices:
appealArgumentTextFive: Direct the appellant to answer one or more clarifying questions about the appeal
Direct the appellant to attend a face-to-face Case Management Appointment
fourStagesPage.appealArgumentTextSix: Once a Tribunal Caseworker is happy that the case is ready to proceed, they direct the Home Office to review the information the appellant has provided. At this stage, the Home Office may decide to withdraw to grant the appeal.
fourStagesPage.hearingText: If the Home Office does not choose to withdraw, the case will go to a hearing.
fourStagesPage.hearingTextTwo: The appellant submits hearing requirements, the case is listed and the appellant and the Home Office are sent a Hearing Notice, which details the location and time of the hearing and other relevant details.
fourStagesPage.decisionText: After the hearing, the Judge writes their decision and uploads it to the online service.
fourStagesPage.decisionTextTwo: The appellant is notified that it is ready to view and can sign in to get their decision.
fourStagesPage.decisionTextThree: If the appeal is dismissed, the appellant is given instructions on what they can do next.

offlineProcessesPage.title: Offline processes
offlineProcessesPage.text: Some parts of the appeal will be managed via email for a time.
offlineProcessesPage.afmtText: If an appellant needs more time to complete a task, they can email applications@justice.org.uk. The appellant must include the reason why they need more time and provide supporting evidence if they can
offlineProcessesPage.withdrawText: Appellants can apply to the Tribunal to:
bullets: withdraw their appeal
expedite their appeal
adjourn their appeal
transfer to a different hearing centre
offlineProcessesPage.withdrawTextTwo: If an appellant needs to make any of these applications, they can email applications@justice.org.uk The appellant must include the reason they are making their application and provide supporting evidence if they can.
offlineProcessesPage.askForJudgeTitle: Ask a Judge to review a decision
offlineProcessesPage.askForJudgeText: A Tribunal Caseworker may make a decision that an appellant wants to challenge. For example, a Tribunal Caseworker may refuse a request for more time or a transfer. In this case, an appellant can ask for a Judge to review that decision. To do this, the appellant must email judge.review@justice.org.uk within 14 days.
